author: projectnewm
title: Kogmios Open Source Doc/Dev/Support
description: There exists a limiting number of ways to interact directly with the Cardano blockchain in a high-performance way.

f6_assessments.q0: Kotlin is a programming language that preferred by Android mobile developers, this proposal intends to open source its Kogmios protocol of client implementation in Kotlin, which I believe would help increase the number of Android developers in Cardano blockchain apps, as there are missing efficient tools for developers to interact with Cardano blockchain, to obtain blockchain information effectively, this proposal addresses the challenge well.
f6_assessments.q1: Andrew the developer who is going to fulfill all the components in this proposal, has a high status on github, an open source host that is most used by developers worldwide, and he has related projects that perform blockchain interactions like airdropping tokens, which demonstrates his ability to achieve the goal of this proposal. Besides, this proposal is mainly about open source tutorial and documentation, I'm positive that it will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal outlines 3 tasks which can be easily tracked and followed on its open source github homepage. The first task implementation of mini-protocols and be validated by its git commits, the second task documenting its libraries can also be easily audited, and the third task is maintenance, can be seen a long term update.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is an under-the-hood request for funding for a Kotlin based "Haskell translator" library that works at the L1.  The popular Ogmios protocol acts as a go between for those uncomfortable interacting at the Cardano base layer in Haskell, instead working in websockets and JSON.  Kogmios (Kotlin) and others like Ogmigo (Go) expand the options even further.

Primarily for projects that are building close to the blockchain itself, or who are customizing from the ground up, projects and labs like blockfrost, eternl, gimbalabs and Mlabs have and are using it, Ogmios has had key impact in the ecosystem, so it can be expected that this added accessibility for developers will be impactful as well.  

With the intention to finalize an already in development opensource library for a project facilitating a lot of innovation, I believe this project merits the full 5 stars for Impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
There is definitely a lack of detail here, though if you know how to parse a repo you can see what has been created to date and also a lot of the initial commits on work still to come, mostly the mini-protocols.  Not an ideal roadmap, for sure, but when added to the provided, short "task list" (which includes create documentation, support) you get some idea of the amount of work left to do.

Likewise the budget isn't very granular, assigning 10K apiece to the deliverables of the library, the documentation, and ongoing support.  This introduces the issue of not providing anywhere an idea of the funding timeline.  Is this a one month project?  3?  6?  The ongoing support suggests a 6+ timeline, but there really isn't any way to know.

The proposer does include links to his previous work (and as mentioned, the Kogmios repo is well underway already) and there is clearly a strong understanding of the work needed and architecture required.  However the lack of key budget insight and especially the lack of a timeline reduces the feasibility by 2 stars, for a rating of 3 stars for Feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2:
The lack of a timeline returns to haunt us here as well.  On its face this should be an easy project to follow:  the repo is opensource, the proposer's projectNEWM will be using the libraries so they will get a test run, and there will be a github project board for pushing it over the finish line.

The question is, where is the finish line?  Or more particularly, when?  This looks like a 3 month project to me, call it 6 to cover support under the funding umbrella, but what does the proposer think?  It would be nice to know, especially for establishing the funding tranches that will be distributed by month.

Because this opensource project from an experienced developer seems to have quite clear and measurable objectives, it has a strong auditability component, however, the lack of timeline to establish funding tranches at the very least forces me to knock it down by one star.  4 Stars for auditability.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposer wants to build an open source library capable of high-performance integration with the cardano blockchain, but as a developer I really struggle to understand the meaning of high performannce, since haskell has the higherst performance with the blockcnain because it was made to be, unlike kotlin. I do like the idea of having a kotlin framework and I agree with the listed benefits, but I wouldn't call kotlin a first class citizen.
There clearly will be a positive impact over the environment and the more languages are involved the better so each developer can find his or her way to contribute on a language already known to them. It's good the authors have already thought about integrations with other dapps that are already existing. I don't know the meaning of mini-protocols and I didn't find anything online so it would have been a good idea to elaborate on that. My suggestion when writing a proposal would be to keep the assumptions to a minimum, because you never know who is going to read and asses your proposal. If it's going to be someone with technical ability or not. The fact that the proposal is in the developer ecosystem, unfortunately doesn't mean only developers are going to asses the proposal. I am a developer, but I still don't know many things about the cardano tools and ecosystem, and a proposal is a good place to educate people while scimultaneously explain your solution to a problem.
I do think this proposal is in line with the challenge settings and will benefit the cardano development ecosystem. I have assessed proposals for the last 3 funds and I find this one to lack details.
Overall this should be a somewhat impactfull proposal if it gets implemented, with the few caveats I mentioned.
f6_assessments.q1:
I do really appreciate the credentials listed in the proposal. I've listed through the repositories linked, and can verify the skills necessary to undertake this project are present, no doubt. The milestones are sufficient, but there's no timeframe given so it's hard to do any estimation on the feasibility of the given tasks and prices for each given item. Looking at the proposal in it's current state, it's hard to have a definite answer if it's feasible or not. On the one hand you have a really experienced developer, but just one that needs to do quite a lot of developing. There's no mention of a team so I don't know if one or 10 people are going to work on this library. On the other hand you can't argue with previous work. It's obvious things get done, but for all the other tooling there were more than one people developing it. 
After reading the proposal I've been left with more questions than answers so I lean towards the uncertanty. The truth is I don't know if this project is feasible or not. If there were more detailed explanation about if it's a team or an individual workin on this, and some kind of a timeframe I would be able to better advise the voters, but as it stands now, I simply can't say.
There's no description of any technicalities except for the language that's going to be used, which is unfortunate. I understand the end goal, but I don't see the road of getting there step by step and the milestones are not enough to give me that picture. Overall a good idea, but the proposal could use some polish. I'd advise the proposers to take a look at excellent proposals from previous funds and check out their structure and try to learn from it. There are many people willing to help in the telegram and discord goups so maybe you can contact some of them to help you with the formulation and aforementioned details.
f6_assessments.q2:
Since the project is going to be open source I don't imagine anyone having problems with following along with the implementation. By the look of the previous projects that were don't the documentation and involvement is good enough that any member in the community that's interested in helping out or finding out more information would be able to do so. I would have liked to seen some kind of a feedback channel, because any framework that's new usually needs beta testers and constant feedback to make it better.
I didn't find a roadmap, but there were some milestones listed without a timeframe. 
I would have liked to see more metrics that can measure adoption, because that would allow the authors to see if they have a positive adoption or not. Metrics are often underestimated, but a process that's not monitored can't be optimized so that's a bit of a hit and miss.
There's a clear description of the problem and a clear solution, of that there's no doubt. I'd suggest for the authors to put on the non-technical voter shoes on and read though their proposals again, and see that a lot of things aren't explained good enough for anyone to understand. Overall an auditable proposal with a few caveats mentioned. Good luck!

f6_assessments.q0:
The project provides a kind of open source library for developers to build applications on the Cardano platform. To develop applications on any platform, a lot of open source application repositories are needed. This proposal introduces an open source library that uses a mini-protocol to interface with the Cardano platform. It is written in Kotlins, so developers can later take advantage of other components on the platform. This proposal helps add value to the Cardano ecosystem because the more quality libraries it has, the easier it is to attract developers.
This proposal has a certain impact on developers, it does not directly attract more developers to the Cardano ecosystem, but when the Cardano ecosystem has a large number of libraries, the more developers will come to Cardano. However, this proposal is not very scalable.
f6_assessments.q1: Andrew Westberg is quite a famous and respected person in the Cardano community, his competence has been proven through the projects he has completed such as Dripdropz, CNCLI. The project is quite special because this whole amount of work needs to be done by only one person. The proposal is also aware of the risk for this reason. Andrew has been involved in quite a few other projects, however the proposal does not specify how he would allocate his time and effort to completing multiple projects. According to the information in the proposal and Github, the project has been under construction, applying for Catalyst funds can accelerate the project. Regarding the project implementation plan, Andrew probably knows what needs to be done to complete the project, however this should be clearly shown in the proposal with detailed plan and specific timelines.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has not given a plan and time to complete each item for the project, so it is difficult for the community to audit the project. Development can only be verified against github channel updates. The KPIs proposed by the proposal are still quite sketchy, so it is recommended to add KPIs such as the number of library usage, the number of errors of the library warehouse. The cost justification is also not reasonable for the amount of 30,000 USD. The project development fee may be charged by the hour, for example. The evaluation of the success of the proposal is also not reasonable. In addition to completing the development of the library for developers, another extremely important factor is the usefulness of this library. It is also worth mentioning the number and frequency of use of the library.

f6_assessments.q0: This project is aiming to create an open-source library capable of using the Cardano network mini-protocols to interact with the Cardano blockchain in a high-performance way. Through the information and data provided, this solution/tool ​​will solve the developer's limitations in direct interaction/communication with the Cardano blockchain and be applied in building Dapps and other blockchain-related products. Although there are clear descriptions of the benefits for the main audience of Challenge - developers, but the author also needs to clarify more about how the library's operating base, architecture, and function nodes will work to help developers build Dapps more optimally. If there were some good examples, case studies, and visual illustrations that describe these things here, it would be great. But previous work experience on similar projects and a commitment to minimal risk that could prevent a proponent's project from succeeding shows that it is a viable and productive project.
f6_assessments.q1: The project development plan is missing some important information, besides providing the work/project outputs, the proponent needs to estimate and add definite timelines for the project complete the stated tasks. Allocate the cost based on the 3 main activities of the task, but since there is no confirmed information about the overall work time, the time worked for each task, it is difficult to conclude whether the proposed cost is appropriate for their work effort/performance. The feasibility of this project is completely predictable, the documentation linking to the previous work of the main member of the project shows that he has a lot of relevant experience and knowledge deeply into the main area of ​​​​this work.
f6_assessments.q2: The tool presented for project management and monitoring is the open-source GitHub project for the library, it is efficient and suitable. However, the proponent has yet to design for this project a clear audit roadmap, Know that product completion isn't everything, and it doesn't equate to success. We also need to monitor its applicability/popularity and user feedback after the product is officially put into use at various stages, which will help sponsors an overview of the project's development potential in the future.

f6_assessments.q0:
I appreciate the idea of ​​this project because as a Cardano participant, I understand that for the platform to really grow and be more diverse, we need to add a lot of applications and products, so it is necessary for great involvement of the developers' community. The project creates a library where open-source code can make it easier for developers to access and implement their plans and products on the Cardano platform, certainly a Very realistic and promising idea. Simplifying the developer's work benefits them, but it also benefits Cardano in having more new, exciting things. We can see this in many other platforms like iOS or Android, they are all successful with having open source libraries so that creators can develop their apps there.
I believe that if the project is successful, it will definitely attract a lot of freelance developers who are cherishing building their applications or products on this platform.
f6_assessments.q1:
This is not a very large and massive project so it is completely feasible, which can be clearly seen in the distribution of the project's work duration. Moreover, the project is led by a leader who is quite reputable in the Cardano community, having successfully implemented many projects before. However, this is also a worrying point because the project implementation apparatus other than him did not specify the people involved. The proposal needs to be written more clearly and completely in terms of the timeline as well as the participants. The point of interest is that this project is being worked on before funding shows that the leader is quite enthusiastic about contributing to Cardano as he usually does. If funded, the level of success and completion of this source code library can be better.
In addition, the project does not specifically describe the ways in which the project engages developers, including those in the Cardano community and outside.
f6_assessments.q2: The project is poorly written in the data, KPIs and capital allocation that are funded from the fund. So if funded, we do not have a comprehensive view of how to allocate 30000 usd. Meanwhile I think the KPI setting for this part can be completely based on the actual number of source code, how much capacity, number of developers involved. And even more importantly, is the user feedback about the source code inside the library effective? Will they come back for more? This just proves the efficiency and quality of this source code library.

The author of the proposal put forward the idea of ​​​​using mini-protocol to communicate with being built with Kotlins, which helps developers get the most out of this library. As for the team , it can be seen that the person implementing the project is a familiar and reputable face in the community with many previous projects. The project has also been partially implemented. Hopefully, with funding, the project completion process will be faster and the level of completion of this library will be better.
f6_assessments.q2: The audit and KPU part of the project is quite sketchy. The establishment of KIP as well as capital allocation have not been clarified by the authors. While we can rely on the amount of source code, or the number of new and old developers involved in use, the number of bugs ... to understand the KPI of the project.

solution: Ogmios is an open-source library capable of using the cardano network mini-protocols to interact with the Cardano blockchain in a high-performance way. Kogmios makes this trivial to use from Kotlin.
experience: Andrew has already delivered many tools to the cardano community and has a deep knowledge of the mini-protocols. He developed CNCLI and gave leaderlogs to the SPO community a year before IOG released similar functionality. Phyrhose, and JorManager are also among previous work.
